content:
r 15, 2016
General:Personal rating: 6/10Not a "The Sims Bustin' Out" but definitely better than Sims 4 and more advanced than Sims 2. Play this if you want a good and recent Sims for computer, forget about the other versions. Watch out, not all DLCs / Expansions are good. Island Paradise is mentioned to be extremely laggy. Best to play the original version without any expansions for the most fluent gameplay! (This applies to the players with average computer systems)Below some extra notes for those who want to read more, or seek the enlightment for this game.Stability:The Sims as a whole has always had some stability issues, if you accidentally find the trigger. The game itself has a stability issue over time. If you play in one neighborhood and let it grow, i.e let Sims reproduce, have new families added to the town, etc. you may eventually encounter so called "lag spikes". It's something comparable to your screen freezing, but only for 1-3 seconds, while the sound continues to work, the world will freeze shortly. These lag spikes are going to occur at a certain point, once your neighborhood is "full". There is no limit in theory, yes, but once there are too many entities in an actively progressing neighborhood, you will see that the game starts to have issues with that. Trust me, this is not a problem about your hardware being outdated, it is the poor coding and entity clearing/resetting of the game. I suggest keeping the amount of neighborhood sims and families to a lower level. Remember, you can always force them to die, either on a natural way, or through the debug console!Pro tip: Can't fix your neighborhood, but at least want to keep your family with their house? Copy the entire household with building, then delete your neighborhood in the main menu and create a new one. You can then add the copy of your original family + house to any new neighborhood, regardless which map you picked and the game will run fluently again!Expansions:Not all are really good in content, value and stability, as I've figured through research and opinions from friends. I suggest the following for the best content and most fluent gameplay in combination with other expansions: Seasons, Supernatural, Pets and Generations. You won't need any other, in my opinion. Island Paradise should be completely ignored, it's known to be one of the most problematic ones. IMPORTANT: The more expansions you buy and the more DLC you add to the main game, the more unstable it will become! This is no joke, even if your computer is "overkill" for this game, the game will still ♥♥♥♥ itself. Blame the developers...Downloadable Content (DLC):I suggest to research the web with Google to find free downloadable content such as maps, hair styles, clothes and items, since Origin is one greedy crowd of ♥♥♥♥♥. Takes you less than 5 minutes. Check out the blogs of Sims gamers, since any other kind of site will most likely add a virus to your file - that includes downloads from Youtube video descriptions too!Hardware & SettingsPersonally I play on a high-end machine, which is why I do not encounter the casualties of hardware compatibility problems. In case you have some, focus on having a good processor and video card (graphics card). 4k RAM is enough if you don't run anything else and 4k RAM is the least people own nowadays - the very least. If yours is above the "minimum" suggested by the developer, but your game feels sloppy and performs badly, you may make changes in the games settings for improvements. Alternative you may have to upgrade your hardware or buy a new PC if you can't do that by yourself. However, it's Sims we are talking about and a good processor should do the job.Remember: You can lower the graphics settings tremendously in this game, which will help you a lot if playing on an older PC. Additionally you may turn off the active neighborhood progression setting in the game options. Then your neighborhood is not going to "play" in the background and will only change if you are in range of these Sims.Community:The modding / content creator community of Sims 3 is overall better and bigger as far as I've figured. Maybe it is because the game created a bigger boom when it came out unlike Sims 4.Personal Sims Experience:I've always been a fan of this simulation series, and have played the following Sims games (in the same order): The Sims Bustin' Out, UrbZ Sims in the City, The Sims (1), The Sims 2, The Sims 3. I've never played Sims 4 due to obviously bad reviews, and I suggest you shouldn't either. All of the Sims games that I've played over the years, through my childhood up to being an adult myself, they were all great in their own way, but unfortunately none was perfect.I hope that one day the developers will decide to actually create a quality Sims, that covers all of the most wanted features for the fans, without ruining the performance.- I have made several edits in this review over my time playing the game -

												Did you love Sims 1, Sims 2? You'll love Sims 3. ...If you want to pay this much for very little... What made the previous Sims so fun? The excessive options in clothing, furniture, etc. With Sims 3, its a little different. You'll pay 40 for the standard, and being a Sims fan you'll spend another additional 20-40 bucks for an expansion. What you think you get? A world full of options, diversity and the start of loads of fun. What you actually get? A hollowed out game. Lacking content compared to the earlier games. The diversity of clothing, furniture, house options, etc, its been minimized. But, EA, being as lovable as they are will give you a chance to add some of that content back.You want to use this piece of furniture? Yes? Pay extra money. Oh you want to make use of the different towns in your options menu? Well, better pay some more money. This particular shirt is featured today, if you want it.. you better pay more money. Sims 3 will use any and all means neccesary to make you pay more money for stuff that should've been in the game in the first place. You buy the 'locked' stuff with points. These points can only be purchased with real money and there is no way to earn them. You pay for a pedigree dog, and you get an emaciated mutt.I love Sims 3, but dont bother buying it unless its on one hell of a sale.

content:
2014
												This game is ridiculously huge to begin with, but for some strange reason it doesn't seem to have enough of the essential content to create a good story with the sims. I mean, in some ways it's a lot like Sims 2 (which I have loved for so many years), but in other ways, its frustratingly different. For example, in Sims 2, I felt satisfied with the game that I bought -- even though I hadn't bought any expansion packs yet. The game was able to stand on its own and impress me without having any extra content. With Sims 3, I feel this horrible dissatisfaction with the content, dispite the superior graphics and the exciting new *live* neighborhood. Oftentimes I can ignore the feeling, but some times it is dishearteningly glaring. There is always this subconsious push to run back to steam and grab up more DLC so that the game can achieve some kind of tolerable level of "rightness" -- almost as though EA was trying to do this on purpose. It seems awful, but I am starting to believe that they just broke the game up into pieces, called it DLC, and tried to sell it to people piecemeal!An additional problem, and a rather gamebreaking one for me, is the sheer size of this game. Once you build it up to a reasonable level with "Pets" "Ambitions" and "Nightlife", things start to go seriously wrong. Bugs and glitches that once were just annoyances become major problems, lag that was pretty tolerable before is now making you mad, and loading times that were originally only a lengthy 5 minutes are now running into the range of 20 minutes -- and this is on the lowest settings possible! I have also begun to experience issues with the game essentially *growing* the more I play it. It automatically starts to get fatter and more sluggish every time. Not to mention the crazy amount of inconvienient game crashes!All in all, I suppose coming so late to the game, I should have heeded the bad reviews and steered clear of it, but as you all know, sometimes, in pursuit of a dream, a gamer is tempted to try something that they know probably sucks.  I would only recommend this game to someone with a ton of patience and a 5 star computer system :P

content:
ry 2, 2014
												Sims 3 Is an insult not just a ♥♥♥♥♥♥ gameThere are two main points to why Sims 3 is a terrible game. Despite the graphical advancements and optimization that make Sims 3 a much smoother game than previous titles, Sims 3 fails to deliver an actually game experience that is rewarding. This and atrocious advertising by EA/Maxis make the game a flop. Here are the reasons broken down. 1) In game advertising. This was such a new low in all my time of playing video games. At every turn, the game is selling you something more. IN THE GAME!!! And if its not useless then its obviously removed from the final product. Selling 20 DLC is one thing (that I object to FYI) but selling you furniture in the game building menu, loading screens that were for DLC, and then asking you to post your screen shots on Facebook... wow that is just putrid. Your playing of the Sims 3 is not a game, but an extended infomercial. 2) I simply found Sims 3 to be a series of mini-games rolled into one. Career advancement, needs, lifetime aspirations, friendships, it was all just so boring to check off one task after another to satisfy each 'aspect' of the game. None of these things made a difference with each other. Dont go to the bathroom and ♥♥♥♥ yourself? no worries, this has no affect with the sim you're talking to. Cheat on your sim significant other? who cares, you'll still get a promotion at work. Achieve the lifetime aspiration? not a bid deal, since you'll get one more pointless talk bubble with another sim that wont mean anything. Its just frustrating to see that the game has so many aspects that play like mini-games since they have no bearing on anything else. You'd think a close sim dying would remove options for your playing sim since a traumatic death would scare/encourage certain developments. NopeAlso failure in the game means nothing. Got rejected from WooHoo? Got fired? Got a sim cheating on you? this will not hinder or alter the game for your sim’s life. How can this be a game mechanic for success?If you are of the perspective that in game sales aren’t a big deal, well then this failure of gameplay can’t be ignored. What a sad story this franchise has had, going from on eof the most popular games out there (16 million units sold for Sims 1) to a laughing stock example of DLC cash cows.I'm sure this review is irrelevant now, seeing the Sims 4 being pushed heavily, yes you called it, in the Sims 3 game right now. I waited for Sims 3 to hit rock bottom retail price since I only really wanted the housing design aspect. But having enjoyed Sims 1 and Sims 2 for the game itself, I am disheartenly justified in waiting so long to get this game at 80% off.

[DO NOT do this in real life])   OR Build your own mansion master piece, town etc. You dont have muscles? This game will give you muscles! Dont have big coconuts? This is a game that you can play until you get over it but then be able to come back and pick up where you left off or start over from scratch.I bought Sims 3 + Multiple DLC packs for $80 (RRP was roughly $200) a few years ago and I dont regret it. Even though it sits there for a while collecting virtual dust due to it becoming repetitive and stale - I am currently back into it. I grab the DLCs while on sale and the additions keep it fresh, interesting and a good variety! content:
ber 22, 2016
												I don't normally review, but I wanted to counter the baseless negative ones that I've seen popping up. I've loved my time with this since I brought it a couple of days ago and haven't put it down. Incredibly fun and diverse gameplay that doesn't stop being entertaining with or without DLC. The community is vast and amazing, so even if you get bored with what you can come up with there are always challenges and mods to download galore. On the topic of DLC, listen up folks - you're not supposed to buy it all, and you don't have to. The stuff packs are just decoration and not worth buying. The EPs - University Life, Late Night, Supernatural - add /different/ worlds and specific themed content ouside of the base game. The only ones that are integral really are Generations, Ambitions, Seasons and Pets. Which all come in a cheap bundle together during this sale season. Buy what looks good to YOU instead of wanting all the DLC for no reason.

												If you liked The Sims and\or its sequel, I'm sure you will like The Sims 3.Think about The sims 2 and add: better graphic, better AI, better skills ad job rewards, bigger neighborhoods, collections (metals, rocks, insects and fishes), free roaming through your neighborhood and complete customization of both color and texture of every object you can buy (consider that the last two features are, years after release, still missing from The Sims 4!).The "only" negative thing I can say about The Sims 3 is that, as time passes by, your savegame will become bigger and slower to load, for example: I've 4 expansions installed, a 5 story house with hundreds of objects in it and 3 sims, it takes about 30 minutes to load (with a Core i7, 16gb of ram and about 500GB of free disk space) and I'm forced to save every 10 minutes or the game fail to save and corrupts the savegame. Sadly support and updates have stopped few years ago.

												Sims 3 is a very good game, from its financial teachings of life to its teaching on the stages of life, and eventually death. It also teaches about the Career Ladder, of which many workplaces may have, depending on your skills (which is also implied on the game) and if you have a healthy relationship with colleagues. So therefore the last time I played it, it completely disheartened my gameplay experience as my computer was unable to cope and crashed many times. But, well done anyway EA, well done!

content:
0, 2014
												Pros: There's lots of customization available to you as you create your sims, both in looks and personality, so you can easily and creepily recreate your old uncle Frank and live out his life if you really wanted to... Their AI isn't horrible, and they will self-perserve as best as possible without your input (although they're still horrible at it). There are also a lot more interactions with the world and other sims that help flesh out your little community.Cons: You need the DLCs. Maybe not all of them, but you need at least one of the larger expansions and a few content packs. The base game is okay, but it's obvious that a lot of things that should have been in the base game, such as modifications and extra options for various careers, were not in specifically so EA could sell it to you later. And as always, the more add-ons you have, the worse the game performs, so there's always this balancing act. Pro?Con?: You will wonder where the last 8 hours of your day went... frequently.Verdict: I can only recommend this game earnestly if you are okay with buying some of the DLC. If not, then you're in for maybe 15 hours or so of enjoyment before you get bored of having the same items, doing the same careeers, and generally following the same path over and over again.

content:
, 2016
												If you'd like to sire a legion of ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s and take over a town, play this game.  If you ever wanted to become a president or CEO just by showing up to work, play this game.  If you ever wanted to become best friends with the Grim Reaper, play this game.  If you enjoy in-depth and potentially catastrophic character creation, play this game.  If you want to construct a family more dysfunctional than your real-life one just to watch the drama unfold, play this game.  If you ever wanted to pollute the gene pool of a town with your own genetic code to the point where reproduction between current residents is no longer a viable option, play this game.  If you've never seen someone literally die of embarrassment, play this game.  There are a thousand other reasons to play this game, but if you don't want to deal with the consequences of not micromanaging (or mismanaging) the actions and interactions of your characters, you will probably end up with a lot of dead Sims (which is not necessarily a bad thing).  It's a funny, tongue-in-cheek game with loads of opportunity and replay value; I'd say stay away from the overpriced DLC (and Sims 4, too) until/unless you are totally, irredeemably bored with this one, because the base game alone provides plenty of traits, jobs, skills, etc. to keep you busy for a while.  The base town with the same cast of NPCs does start to get dull after a while, but you probably only need one or two DLC towns at most and if you don't wanna pay, then you can create your own town with your own people.  If you have a decent/recent PC, it should run fine -- a little laggy, but nothing that destroys the experience.  One of my personal all-time favorites; it's not a perfect game, but if you enjoy dicking around with other people's lives and relationships, you will not be disappointed.  10/10 would forget to go to my own wedding/first childbirth again

content:
2, 2014
												I really enjoyed playing the base game until I started to invest in the expansion packs.  Stability problems, freezing and random quitting were some of the problems I've experienced.  It's a shame because I've always enjoyed the series.  But it seems that the more expansion packs you add, the more problems seem to show up.  It was running OK for a while when I had just installed Night Life...I only noticed some slowdown here and there.  However, I picked up three expansion packs during the Steam Winter sale.  In doing so, my game became unplayable.  My previous towns were all suddenly gone and any game that I created thereafter always became corrupt.  It's rather frustrating and I wish I could get my money back at this point.  Forums don't seem to be of much help either.  I just had my computer built in Spring 2013 with WIndows 8, so my computer is not the issue.In the end, I DO recommend the base game to loyal fans.  However, just be warned that the expansion packs may completely ruin your ability to play, regardless of how new your computer is.  Since the expansion packs are what previously made this game's replayability so high, overall it's a disappointment and I regret having wasted money on broken expansion packs.

content:
6, 2014
												Hmm. I am dissapointed and um... angry actually. This is one of the most dissapointing games I have ever played. Not because of gameplay, that part is great... when and if it happens. This is the most buggy thing I have ever played. I read the online reviews which warned me, but I have a great gaming computer with lots of resources and processing power, what could go wrong? My real issue (as far as I can tell) comes from the paradise island add on which consistently stalls and has a huge bug... I tried setting everything down way low but it was still stalling all the time. I would just go elsewhere (like university) and all would be fine, so I mostly played there. But i went on an 'adventure' and when i 'returned home' i got dumped on a tiny island with no ability to move physically at all and I mean at all,  no home no money no access to the other panels for phone or anything else. I have repeatedly gone back to my save and tried again but its the same thing and I can't go anywhere else... the worst part is that when the 'adventure' times out it just takes me there again and I can do no more. When you invest a fair amount of time building a character, which is what sims is all about, and then it gets destroyed by a glitch it really is annoying, and for a game that is this incredibly expensive it's inexcusable. If you still decide to pour your money down this money grubbing hole, don't get paradise island and really look at the forum for issues others are having before considering any other add-ons.  And hey Maxis, when you make a game this badly perhaps you want to take the time to fix it before putting out another rendition. Just sayin.

content:
er 28, 2013
												In some ways, this game isn't realistic enough.  I have an Irish wolfhound, and a burglar broke into my house and stole my things, all without a peep out of the dog!  Seriously?!  The dog had already been told to guard the house several times - which let's face it, you wouldn't have to do with a real dog, especially a breed like this, we're not talking chihauha here!  The dog should be programmed to automatically guard, and the burglar should be afraid of it.  Also, your dog runs away if you only feed it for a couple of days or so, and don't hug it, or play with it, or walk it, treat it, brush it ....In other ways, the game is eerily realistic.  By the time my Sim gets up, showers, brushes her teeth, makes some breakfast, feeds the dog, plays with the dog, hugs/treats/or brushes the dog, takes out the trash, and recycles the newspaper, it's time to go to work.  And my sim only has a part-time job!!  Then she has to come home, make dinner, do the whole dog thing again, maybe find a bit of time to read a skill book, and go to bed.   Way, way, way too much like real life.  Except that I have a full-time job in real life.  Why on earth would I want to play a game that was as filled with mundane tasks and routine as my own life?  People play games to escape from that!  I know, you can change the time speed.  But shouldn't the devs have already set it up as a default that the routine things don't take so long to do, so you don't have to constantly play with the time settings?  and shouldn't they have set it up so your sim knows what to do after you've done the same routine at roughly the same time on the same days, and your sim just goes and does it superfast, leaving you more time to go off and do other things in the game?  am I supposed to set this up, making routine lists and feeding them to my sim?   If I leave my sim alone to do things, she does stupid, pointless things like reading and re-reading Where's Bella, over and over again.  Maybe I just don't know how to play this game, I know it's a popular game, and maybe there's a way around these problems that my 20  hours or so of playing hasn't been enough for me to find.   I get bored quick, though, so if a game can't me interested within that 20 hours, forget it.    Sims3 gets a big thumbs down from me.

content:
6, 2014
												What a wonderful game!   It's really fun to play and it's like no other game made ever.   You could easily waste away hours on such a entertaining game.Why do I not recommend it then you ask?   Easy.   Nothing ever works right.   The developers are more worried about getting the next DLC released so they can get more cash.   They really don't care if all the features in the game or the DLC don't work.  Oh?   You sent our sim to university and then it just vanished making the game unplayable?   Who cares because we already have your money!  Fun stuff.It's really a shame that we, as consumers, put up with garbage like this.   If a game isn't complete it should not be released as a complete game. Then telling people the new DLC (which cost more money) will fix the problems. Then that DLC causes problems that you have to buy the next DLC to fix.   See what I am getting at?  This game is fun but the people who made it are more worried about coming up with ways to squeeze more money out of you than they are making an enjoyable gaming experience.When you look at the number of players in the community and the number of DLCs for this game it doesn't take Adam Smith to figure out this title is raking in the cash.  You would think with that kind of money flowing the developers could at least spend a real effort getting rid of the bugs.   After two or three years games should not have bugs that make it totally unplayable.Ask yourself.   Do I really want to experience the frustration of spending money on something that infuriates me before I get through the registration process?  Am I going to spend money on a game and time creating a sim just to have them vanish when I try to use the extra content?I wish somebody would file a class action law suite against these guys.  If they had a real threat to their money perhaps then they would start making software that functions as advertised.

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
7, 2014
												My review of this game is easily mixed, the game is very fun to play and enjoyable, but much more so with the downloadable content, or only a fraction of it.  Most of it is about half as expensive as the game itself where other content is even more expensive than that, there's plenty of useless add ons that only add a few cosmetic changes and nothing else.  More or less it's devided into two seprate groups.  Actual content and "Stuff" packs, the actual content is viable if it weren't more expensive, where as the "Stuff" packs only add a couple new stuff, ussually stuff that won't affect gameplay in the slightest outside of just being able to buy a couple extra stuff for twenty dollars.  Essentially the only reason I got this game due to the price was because of a 75% sale that was going on, doing research on every little pack just in case I missed something, I've narrowed down some essentials to get if you purchase this game, but I'd only do so when it's on a 75% sale due to the fact all the DLC is over 250 US$ not including the game itself.Needs:Seasons: Adds a couple new traits, a lot of new winter coats plus normal everyday clothes ussually themed with seasons, as well as adds dynamic weather and a threat of dying from weather or getting miserable sun burn.Pets: Adds a bunch of pets to the game, from cats, dogs, and horses which you can control to birds turtles and other non-controlable characters.  You'll spend a little less time speeding through your day when your sim is taken up at work or asleep this way.Generations: Adds quite a few new traits and a new theme, scrapbook, which stores your memories, the pictures are taken a bit wonky half the time but it also lets you pick your wish no matter what which is always a plus.The rest is based on oppinion such as a couple I haven't gotten, supernatual comes to mind on this one.You should avoid at all costs unless you feel 100% sure it'll add a lot to your experiance is all the stuff packs.  Mostly servering souly for role play aspects (Which the modding community glady contributes as well for free) your packs come with generally a couple new things for males and a handful for females (very lopsided men are less important than females in this game it seems) these packs server only to take your money, in fact my suspicion is that the reasoning behind using your codes on the sims 3 website you get with your games is souly because EA Games is so terrified people will find out it's a bad deal and just hack the stuff into the game, which wouldn't surprise me given their more or less monopolistic aproach.Verdict is the game is a avoid at all costs as you'll want to get a bunch of map packs, it's saving grace is that the stuff I found contributed to a great game is spending 60 US$ durring a 75% sale going on, but that's about 240 US$ out of a sale just to have a good game and that's only buying less than half the downloadable content.  Don't waste your money, wait for a sale or have been born very rich to not care, but this game so isn't worth the expense out of sale and DO NOT get this game if you don't have high end hardwear, this game will give issues to some better designed computers in its own.

content:
2, 2014
												I really enjoyed playing the base game until I started to invest in the expansion packs.  Stability problems, freezing and random quitting were some of the problems I've experienced.  It's a shame because I've always enjoyed the series.  But it seems that the more expansion packs you add, the more problems seem to show up.  It was running OK for a while when I had just installed Night Life...I only noticed some slowdown here and there.  However, I picked up three expansion packs during the Steam Winter sale.  In doing so, my game became unplayable.  My previous towns were all suddenly gone and any game that I created thereafter always became corrupt.  It's rather frustrating and I wish I could get my money back at this point.  Forums don't seem to be of much help either.  I just had my computer built in Spring 2013 with WIndows 8, so my computer is not the issue.In the end, I DO recommend the base game to loyal fans.  However, just be warned that the expansion packs may completely ruin your ability to play, regardless of how new your computer is.  Since the expansion packs are what previously made this game's replayability so high, overall it's a disappointment and I regret having wasted money on broken expansion packs.

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
6, 2014
												Hmm. I am dissapointed and um... angry actually. This is one of the most dissapointing games I have ever played. Not because of gameplay, that part is great... when and if it happens. This is the most buggy thing I have ever played. I read the online reviews which warned me, but I have a great gaming computer with lots of resources and processing power, what could go wrong? My real issue (as far as I can tell) comes from the paradise island add on which consistently stalls and has a huge bug... I tried setting everything down way low but it was still stalling all the time. I would just go elsewhere (like university) and all would be fine, so I mostly played there. But i went on an 'adventure' and when i 'returned home' i got dumped on a tiny island with no ability to move physically at all and I mean at all,  no home no money no access to the other panels for phone or anything else. I have repeatedly gone back to my save and tried again but its the same thing and I can't go anywhere else... the worst part is that when the 'adventure' times out it just takes me there again and I can do no more. When you invest a fair amount of time building a character, which is what sims is all about, and then it gets destroyed by a glitch it really is annoying, and for a game that is this incredibly expensive it's inexcusable. If you still decide to pour your money down this money grubbing hole, don't get paradise island and really look at the forum for issues others are having before considering any other add-ons.  And hey Maxis, when you make a game this badly perhaps you want to take the time to fix it before putting out another rendition. Just sayin.

content:
15, 2014
												Sims 3 is a simulation of................ LIFE!!!!!The game is complex and well designed enough to let the gamers enjoy the possibilities of "life" as we know it.It is vast enough for the gamers to see every corners of life first hand but it isn't detailed enough to showevery little miniscule details.Depending on how creative "you" are, the game can get extremely fun or extremely deadbeat-boring if you arn't.The game offers some intense customisationHouses, sims, jobs, family, are some aspects that are fully customizable down to every individual faces.It is a must try and a worthwhile buy(base game) quality wise.They have their own version of a contents sharing communitites, the gamers are able to download various player made people, buildings, objects from the internet.Similar to EA's spore, this is one of their trademark franchise that has not failed them, (for a damn good reason.)The pros are explained above, the cons are:-The game greeds money, it really WANTS you to make purchases for ingame items, DLCs etc.-DLCs make the game more fun, THEY ARE INDEED FUN but imagine how much money you'll have to pay for various DLCsyou want.(if the prices have dropped to primal dollar values then reconsider the statement above)-The game can get addictive, it can seriously chew up some valueable time.-After you play the game for a long bit, it can start to lag horribley due to cummulated cache and such, so consider ventilating a bit.- Sims4(or versions above?) would be out. It would be more versatile than the previous sims3 and possibly more fun.-It is reccomended you use Origin :(If you "love" and "somewhat respect" their game, consider buying it... If you wish to be frugal and do not want to spend every penny for their DLCs then please torrent safely :)

content:
er 1, 2013
												It's a shame that The Sims 2 isn't available on Steam (and that I seem to recall it having big issues running on later versions of Windows), because that's the best entry in the series. I gave this entry a fair shake, but ultimately didn't like it. My biggest criticism might be that building and designing your house is a thousand times more complicated than the last game, which some people might actually consider a plus. I consider myself to have an obsessive attention to detail, but this game overwhelmed me. Do you want to position your furniture at an angle? What about BETWEEN grid spaces? Do you want to decide the precise shade of every single object in your house? Again, some people might love these new features, but I missed the days when everything snapped to a simple grid and color options were limited. A few constraints allow creativity to blossom, you know? My biggest problem with building and designing, however, is not the overwhelming amount of options but the fact that it just felt less intuitive. In The Sims 2, I knew what all the building tools did and if I had a piece of furniture in mind, I had a pretty good idea where to find it. Not the case with this game. Wait for Sims 4, or go retro.

content:
y 23, 2016
												The Sims 3 is a great game. Many people will say that The Sims 2 or The Sims 4 is better. The Sims 3 is the best Sims game because it has open world. I can't imagine a Sims game without open world. Open world allows you to travel to anywhere in the town. After the initial two-three loading screens, the only loading screens you'll encounter are when you use a mirror to change appearance, a dresser to plan outfit, or if you move, and even then these loading screens are quite short. You can customize your Sims fully, with all of the basics and many more clothing, accessories, hairstyles, and outfits available. Whatever you don't have, you can most likely get from The Sims Store, which you need an account for. You use your money to gain SimPoints, the currency used. While The Sims Store is overpriced and it will cost hundreds of dollars to buy all of the items, if you want to make an emo Sim, you will be able to buy all of the emo clothes, haircuts, and furniture without spending too much money.Enough about The Sims Store. The Sims 3 is great because of the endless possibilities. You can have an amazing variety of Sims, all with different personalities (which are fully customizable,) careers, houses, families, and Lifetime Wishes. The game runs very smoothly on my computer. There are also Skills and Opportunities, somewhat similar to real life. Opportunities will randomly be presented to you, with a brief description of the Opportunity, usually with some humour added in too. Opportunities often require you to do something in exchange for a reward. You may have to visit certain areas, fix broken objects, make food for certain establishments or Sims, or stay in late after work ends. Rewards vary, and may include better relationships with co-workers, bosses, or other Sims, job or school performance, Simoleons (in-game money,) or Skill gain. Opportunities often have a deadline. Skills are like skills in real life. Skills include Writing (typing), Painting, Gardening, Cooking, Handiness, Charisma, and many more. You can build Skills by practicing, which is different for each Skill, or by doing tasks that improve that Skill, as each Skill is useful for a specific task. You can also build Skills by reading books, watching TV channels, learning from other Sims or by having certain Traits.Overall, The Sims 3 is a good game that has unlimited replayability. It has its cons, however. The same old Sims get boring quickly, as Sunset Valley, the town that comes with the game, always has the same Sims when it is first started. However, the starting Sim's babies and descendants can vary. By creating an account, you get another town for free. A few other cons are that in a household of 8 (the maximum amount) Sims, it is really hard to have fun. You are constantly taking care of their Needs, which are Hunger, Bladder, Hygiene, Fun, Social, and Energy, and the rest of the time you are building Skills or Relationships, or improving job performance. Also, the stuff packs and expansion packs don't add very much, and are overpriced. The Sims Store is also overpriced.

ber 29, 2016
												724 hours played and I still haven't done everything in the game. Bored of your character? Create another one!Bored of the town? Use/Download another one! (or even create your own)You don't need all the DLC to have fun with this. There is the very rare crash, but I've just made the rule to save every in-game-night and then alt-tab and do other things whilst it's saving. It takes a while to load but the beauty of it is that you only need to load it once and that's it. Enjoy playing your game for the next 24 hours without a loading screen!There are the micro-transactions in-game but you don't NEED any of it. It's all just for show. If you really want something fancy, that's what the 'Create-a-Style' is for. Make a couch with puppy dogs printed all over it, I dunno, up to you. It's an amazing game, terribly addicting, and IMO will always be the best Sims game.

												I have more hours than steam says i do. steam stopped tracking my hours but i had about a thousand hours on origin. This game is addicting and for a period of time, took over my life. The sims allows you to do whatever you want with people. I usually make OTPs and ships on the sims or my friends when they date irl. When one breaks up with someone irl i kill their sim. this is game super fun and expansion packs make it better. although i wish expansion packs were cheaper. You can do almost anything in Sims 3. One expansion pack that is my favorite and that I highly reccomend is Generations, I love playing as families on Sims 3 so this expansion pack was perfect. It adds so much to the game. It adds a new trait, new things you can interact with sims and also imaginary friends which is super fun. It also adds many more useful items like potions. Pets is also a very good expansion pack but I find i crash sometimes when i use it so save often. Pets adds, well pets and other animals that you can collect. it also adds new traits like the Cat Lover, Dog Lover, Animal Lover and etc.. Here are some expansion packs i reccomend you buy at your own risk: 1. Island ParadiseI bought this pack a few months ago and it was so cool, there were boats and houseboats and even a new neighborhood! There was so much more too, hot tubs and resorts there was so much that i cant even begin to tell you. Thats probably one of the things that causes the problem. The problem is that the game lags really badly and crashes every 15 minutes sometimes less. Its probably because of all the stuff in it. The expansion pack would definatly be my absolute favorite if it werent for the lag and crashing2. SupernaturalIts cool and all with the different creatures but it takes over your game. Thats really all I have to sayThose are the only two I really reccomend looking out for but consider I have not bought all the expansion packs considering how steam has a summer sale once a year and how I am broke most of the time. Thank you for reading this review I know i went off topic kinda but i do that alotSims 3: 10/10 one of the best games Ive played.

content:
3
												I've been playing The Sims 3 ever since it first came out, but I'm going to be reviewing this as someone who also plays The Sims 4 most of the time. I decided to revisit The Sims 3 after missing expansion packs like University and Seasons. I have a pretty good laptop that runs Sims 3 very well, but it's a game that I think no matter what kind of system you play on will be filled with lag and some glitches. It makes sense considering in the Sims 3, compared to every other game in the series, takes place in an open world. That's what makes the Sims 3 so great, being able to go to the library without a loading screen, or having my sim take a dog for a walk. Character customization compared to the other games, is way better. You have such extensive customization you can get lost in create a sim for a good hour. It's a good thing imo. The negatives, and the biggest reasons I play The Sims 3 not as much as I  use to is I find the character models blah compared to the Sims 4 (and even The Sims 2 tbh), in order to have a good variety of items you need to purchase a lot of expensive stuff packs and whatnot, which sucks (I think for the most part all the main game expansion packs are fun and worth the price for the most part). Along with the online store, just having to pay more money for things I think should be included in the expansion packs. I'm glad The Sims 4 went away with that. Even though you don't need all the expansion packs (I would say having Generations, Seasons, University and Pets are the only ones really worth having), they are nice to expand gameplay. Overall I think The Sims 3 is worth playing, it's open world, great character customization and fun main game expansion packs will make for a good time.

												It's convenient how I don't need to get out the old disc for Sims 3 when I want to play nowadays. That's probably the biggest benefit of buying it on Steam.  I played this game all the time when it first came out and it's just as fun as it was back then such as lighting people on fire, drowning them in pools, trapping them in a 1x1 room and watching the sims pee themselves, or creating a facility full of slaves/prisoners. Basically finding the best way possible to make every Sim as miserable as possible. If you want to be different, then I guess you could play normally but there's no fun in that.The only thing I noticed however, is that this version seems to have consistent bugs as well as corrupted files or saves so if you end up buying the game, make sure you have some good save files or else you might have to start over depending on how much patience you have.

6, 2016
												I can say that this game is way better than The Sims 4, this game is the one that changes how The Sims work (most of it). Personality is the biggest changes made, in The Sims and The Sims 2 you can only change Neat, Outgoing, Active, etc. but in The Sims 3 this is where personality becomes more specific, from Absent-Minded to Charismatic sims, the base game is already fun but purchasing the DLCs (I'd recommend expansions pack instead of stuff pack) makes the game more complete.The game is open world, so the loading screen may be longer compared to other The Sims.Before purchasing the DLCs make sure to go online to see what features it offers, also ONLY buy the DLC (at least try to) when on sale. because they are overpriced. Want to know why to buy the DLCs on sale? Check the total price of The SIms 3 plus DLCs, it's just mental.-------------------------------------------The downside of this game is.... SHOP mode.... It's just outrageous, I'd rather have community made object than this.... Also performance issue, other Sims games are way less demanding than this, including The Sims 4.

Get off your fat stacks of cash and make the game playable as it's meant to be played, you can't rely on the modding community to fix everything--it's YOUR problem NOT ours.

content:
ber 22, 2016
												The Sims on it's own is good for stretching the creative mind, allowing you to try new achievements and experience different modes, but after a while you're repeating the same formulas and you're sims eventually do the same things regardless of your intended mission in life. It's hard to keep a family going after say the first generation dies as you'll just be repeating everything unless you have more to do. By regularly buying the expansions, the sims will continue to be enjoyable and allow you to try new things. I would suggest buying these on sale however as I don't think they are worth the £29.99 they are charged at.Also the gameplay is slowed down considerably so if you don't have a fast upto date computer only stick to a couple of DLC's. Certain one's are better than others. Into the Future for example is good as it allows you to have new tools and enter new worlds, along with the additional accessories and lifetime achievements. Some however are not as good for the money you pay and only give you extra little bits for your sims and their home but don't really expand the gameplay/

												The sims 3 is a very enjoyable game... WIth the DLC... I mean the core game is fun for the first couple of hours or even the first couple of days but it dries out quickly.There isn't enough to do in the core game and if you want all the DLC you are going to need to pay approximately $400, I recommend getting the game right now during the flash sale or just when the game is on special so you can enjoy the game a little more.Game elements like playing the Piano and going to university should realy be in the core game but no, you are going to have to pay for the "Late Night" DLC if you want a piano, or the "University Life" DLC if you want your sim to go streaking. With the DLC the game is exceptional but it costs far too much money to play the game without getting bored.If you bought all the DLC for $400... You could have bought 50 if not more games for that value, cheap-ish ones of course but there are many impressive indie games out there, especially now that the summer sales are going round so you can get over 100 games and still have some change.But as we all know EA are notorious for DLC so asking for less DLC that is cheaper would be asking too much so only buy this game if you have seen gameplay of the core game and seem interested enough or if you want to play for DLC.

												THE MONEY:The game as it stands, with all its DLCs, is $420. With that, you could buy 8 brand new 60 dollar games, and this base game.The game should come with a few DLCs, like generations and university life. If you ask me, University life is the only one worth 30 bucks, but it should come with the Sims 3 anyway.  Also, some DLCs are way too expensive, like the "Stuff DlCs" that come with a few furnitures and clothes for 20 bucks. Pets adds cats, dogs, and horses I believe. They do nothing but cost you extra money and aren't cute or worth it because you can't pet, ride, or walk them like you would in real life, just clicking buttons. But I suppose thats the whole game. 5/10GAMEPLAY:*sigh*It's fun, however. The base game has lots of content, but it begans getting repetative. It's abunch of time wasting really, click this to do this. Woo-hoo. Oh, and the game is about sex basicly too, and repopulation. I  moved in to my crappy house and a a neighbor and I just started talking. 5 minutes later we were "woo-hooing" or having sex basicly. 8.5/10 for gameplay.PERFORMANCE:Another problem with DLCs, is that they cause the game to crash and become slower with each one. The base game it self, is a buggy crashy mess. It seems every other time you start the game, it slaps you across the face and holds up a big red STOP sign. Then, you have to reinstall it, with 3/10 times that won't work, and you have to dive into the bowels of the steams community archives to find a fix for this SH*T because it's a different problem every hoover dam TIME!!!!  1/10But hey, I still play the mess and keep repeating the reinstall Don't I? *sigh* I have no life.

content:
1, 2014
												There's a lot I want to praise this game for. There's tons of sim customization options here, some very powerful building tools, and some pretty funny situations you can get your sims in. Even the pets have a ton of customization options available to them. In truth, when the mood hits me just right The Sims can feel like an incredibly satisfying game. Why can't I recommend this game then? I have probably over 500 hours clocked into this game on Origin. I have almost all the expansions, and a lot of fun memories with this game. In a lot of ways The Sims is like a seperate hobby branching off of your gaming hobby. The problem is that it's a stupidly expensive hobby for a game and, ultimately, feels like a huge waste of time. No matter what houses or community lots I create or fun families I put together, actually playing the game is often a huge head ache thanks to some pretty miserable pathing choices and unrealistic Sim interactions (why can't they just socialize with the people in the room with them while they are all doing different activities?). I often finding most of my time going into creating new lots for the game, but I have yet to ever make it through an entire generation without the game feeling simply too repetative, unimmersive, or just plain buggy as hell. There are some fantastic mods that can fix a couple of the issues I've pointed out above, but if you're new to the series bewarned that it is, without a doubt, a huge time sink and a very expensive one at that. Ultimately I think the promises of The Sims 4 has potential to fix many of my peevs with the game, but once again, what an expensive game to get into...You have been warned.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
20, 2014
												It actually, actively bothers me that I like this game. Seriously. The Sims is a franchise that has with each new iteration stripped features that used to be free and turned them into expansion packs you have to pay money for, all the while reducing modding capability in favor of trying to nickel-and-dime more stuff out of you to the point that you cannot actually get into the game without getting through a storefront that tries to sell you more things. From a business-practices perspective it's really, really icky and uncomfortable and it makes me feel bad that I still play it....but I still play it. God dammit. EA, why are you the only company that makes good life sims. I'm marking this as a no-recommendation not because you shouldn't play it but rather because it's the only way I can rescue any of my dignity.

content:
5
												Very fun and involving, as always recommmended don't cheat... It honestly kills the experience and a majority of the game's rewarding feeling of working hard in it. That aside, the game is enjoyable if you're looking for a role-playing game in which you immerse yourself into the character and what they do day to day. Between taking care of your needs, keeping up with your job, and maintaining relationships, the game still continues to deliver a great experience for the player.I myself am one who searches for the most enjoyable RPG games, and ones which can offer many things. So, I personally recommend if you're looking for a "Live your Life RPG" get this game with the following DLC:- Seasons -> Creates worlds with 4 Seasons [ More RP Events, Things to do..] + OBJECTS- Pets -> Duh. Pets. [Dogs, Cats, Horses, Birds, Rats, Hamsters, Fish, etc.] + OBJECTS- Generations -> In depth family options + OBJECTS - Late Night -> Celebrity Status + Bars + OBJECTS- Ambitions -> Further Career options + OBJECTS- Town Life Stuff -> To do stuff around Town + OBJECTSAll of these DLCs together will create a very in-depth gameplay experience of your Sim(s) life(s).All in all , Great Game.XAYAH

content:
, 2016
												I highly recommend this game, because I love to create new people and to model out their life. You can do crazy things and make different scenarios, and I think it's an all around pretty good game. I became addicted to it after the first hours or so. EA, of course, will be dangling the expansion/stuff packs in your face, but I had a fun time with the base game. It was cool to create new generations and progress the family tree, and it's not like the Sims 3 is an unfinished game.  The expansion are extremely overpriced, however. The constant nagging to "buy this hairstyle!" and to "buy this awesome expansion pack!" gets annoying quickly, especially if you don't want to fork over your cash for some new furniture. However, now with the summer sale, I think it's definitely a grab. $20 wasn't too bad for the base game, but $5 dollars is really good. If you are only just now buying the game, try to look up some expansion pack reviews too. I'm not trying to promote anything, but if you play the game for a little while and want to buy one, it'll be a lot harder to give $20  than it is to give $5. Final thoughts: I'd give this game a go, even if you are kind of inbetween, mainly because of the summer sale. However, if the sale's over, I'd still think about getting it, but hold off for the expansion packs.

												Create, build, and explore this fun filled adventure were you control the action. You get to create your very own Sim and build a house or a future for yourself. The options to the creativity in this game are endless. There are so many options to what you can do it can be overwhelming at times. You put attributes into your Sim and you can ether dictate every little action your Sim does or let the Sim make its own decisions. The world is massive and you can interact with pretty much everything. You can be what you want to be and do what you want to do. But with every action there is a equal and opposite reaction so remember that when playing this game. Its such an awesome adventure and a very addictive hard game to put down. Just the details that you can put into your home is mind boggling.  I have totally loved playing and creating in this game. If you like a big world were you control a Sim and control the outcomes to an extent then this is a definite do not miss game! I love it!

It's both more of a role-playing game than it's ever been before, and more of a design game than it's ever been before. 												The Sims 3 has introduced a touch more realism to the game via updated graphics, for me the graphics are a little 'too' realistic. The cartoony element of the game is what made me fall in love with it's predecessor The Sims 2.There is extreme creative control with regards to customisation and open-world gameplay.This is not to say that build-mode is simple, however. Certain aspects are likely to cause irritation.Gameplay style has ironed out many old flaws from S2, but as usual there are plenty of new bugs!Despite The Sims 2 being my continued favourite for the series due to the incorporated storylines, The Sims 3 leaves most to the imagination. If played with all expansion packs it only enhances entertainment.Overall, I really enjoy this game. I would recommend to any Sims fan.

content:
, 2016
												I've owned The Sims 3 since release on disc version, but never had any DLC. For the 2016 summer sale, I saw all the DLC was dirt cheap and decided to buy it again on steam with most of the DLC (hence the lack of hours played at the moment). But anyway, the review... I bet most of you at least know what the Sims is all about. It's essentially a goofy life simulator which will eventually turn into your actual life bacause of how addictive it is! You can do pretty much anything you can do in real life... Get a job, get a car, get married, grow old, wet yourself in public and then die...But seriously, being able to have kids and watch them grow up and have kids of their own and build an entire family tree is so amazing. It's my favourite thing about this game and there are so many things to love! I'd strongly recommend Sims 3 over the Sims 4 anyday. It was just designed so much better. I've played every single Sims game and I'd without a doubt say 3 is the superior one. And that's just the base game! The DLC adds so many elements that vastly improve the experience. Seasons, Late night & Generations are must haves for immersion. But feel free to youtube them all and decide which you like best. I'd suggest waiting for a sale to get the DLC though (Like I did) as they are fairly overpriced usually. But to summarise... Yes! I'd recommend this game 100% (even if it was produced by the evil EA company). So stop reading reviews and click buy if you haven't already!

content:
ber 23, 2014
												As sims player since the first game's release in the beginning of 2000, I loved the first one, a promising game that was overall fun, but it felt like aside from babies growing up, the child OR adult never aged, though the soundtrack is the best out of all the main series of Sims, gotta love that jazzy music~. When the Sims 2 out in 2004, a massive improvement to the first one. I loved it to death and spent hours of playing it (Still playing it with the Ultimate Collection!), from abducting sims for the cute aliens, growing my family tree, helping my sims succeed throughout their life with a Summa Cuum Laude in the University Expansion, to raising their skills before their death, and so much more! When The Sims 3 came out, that was a different story, I didn't like it at first, no matter how much I tried to like it with all the expansions I bought, I couldn't. Right before the failure of a sequel known as The Sims 4 came out, I decided to give The Sims 3 one more chance, and finally, I got hooked!Sims 3, like the Sims 2, is a massive improvement to the previous 2, regardless of the ridiculous microtransaction. The game is meant to simulate... Well, life! They even added a open-world aspect to the game! Oh, skills now varies from what you learn, it's not just a general thing like Creativity for arts and music, it's now skills like Guitar, Drums, Piano, Painting, so much more! Even exploring the neighborhood collecting items and finding interesting things for your skills. In some expansions, there is a new Life State I taken a liking to, such as Imaginary friends, a great way to build my family tree since you could make a Imaginary friend of the opposite gender of the owner. Even Aliens make a return in Seasons, and oh~ my~, they're even cuter than Sims 2 with that synthesize voice!Overall, like Sims 2, a massive improvement to the previous Sims. Get it and save your money for the expansions!

content:
y 1
												Game Play 8/10Graphics 8/10-A Bunch of DLC-Time ConsumingAfter playing the sims 3 for around 300 hours I can surely say that the game is fun and provides a enjoyable experience. In Sims you basically make yourself a character or family and go on through the game while seeing your characters grow up. Your family will slowly grow as your starting character begins to grow old and ends up sadly dying as death himself comes through your front door to take your orginal character's soul away. The gameplay is a little bit repetive as you basically give your family characters orders such as cook/eat food or go to work/school everyday until their is a holiday or weekened for them to take off and instead chill at home. You will have to pile up money to expand your house and add new additions to it, which may be a grind, but you may easily use cheats or gain a well paying job to quickly create a fair amount of money. Graphics are nothing to praise or spit on, but it is thankfully easy on the eyes as you will be playing for sometime to see progress take place in your world. One down side is the DLC really which is a valid reason for some negative reviews about this game, yet I wish to note that the game is still fun without any of the DLC. You will still have fun with the base game and if you ever wish to try something new then simply start a new family or pick up one of the DLC packs when they are on sale. I reccomend Sims 3 to those looking for a different game that requires you to have a little bit of devotion to have progress take place. I give Sims 3 9/10 Broken Sinks

content:
er 29, 2016
												Every Sims title to date that I've played manages to make me feel the same way. I just end up being enthralled by it. And while I always felt that The Sims 3 didn't have a lot when it came to base content, it does offer a lot of worthwhile stuff in the expansions – things that I don't really remember being in any of the Sims titles before it.For one, I think even though the learning curve is steeper when it comes to building houses, there are more advanced options and it just feels more complete than it did in The Sims 2 for instance.And I also feel somewhat the same about towns. There's somewhat less freedom when it comes to creating towns from scratch, but you are just given a lot more customisation over that town and it feels more alive. In fact I think customisation is the key word when it comes to The Sims 3 and it applies to more than just the town or colour of the walls. You can customise pretty much anything, from furniture to the clothes your sims wear. And if that's not enough, you can download things from the community that other people have made themselves, or buy other stuff made available on the store.Some might cringe at this sort of thing, but I think in the end its one of the reasons why this game is still played to this day, and I think it has had the longest lifecycle of any Sims title, and why this one in particular is on Steam. Because there was certainly a demand for it. I mean, the fact that I would rather buy this and most of the expansions here than play Sims 2 which Origin offered for free at one stage is a testament to just how good it really is.True, it is buggy, not very stable, and it still leaves something to be desired in terms of graphics, but if you're willing to put up with all of that, I think you'll find it more than a little rewarding, and it will take you ages to get through all of what it has to offer.

content:
2015
 simulation at it's finest This game is fun for the whole family. If you have played any of the other sims games then you know what to expect, make a sim (person) give them a job, find them a girlfriend/boyfriend and start a family. The sims 3 really changed alot with the other sims for example the city is now an open world city so not more one lot houses now the city is your lot. There is so many new things involved with the sims 3 that you cant describe it, you need to just jump in the game and find it. just stunning You may also notice that the graphics got a smooth upgrade. Sims now look more like real people than worn out dolls. Also your needs such as hunger got an update as well so you dont have to eat and use the bathroom every 5 minuets which gives you more time to explore the city or maybe call up a friend and hang out. There are way more sims in the city than there was in the sims 2 cities which leads to a more realistic tone in the game. rewards everywhere As the game is fun you will find that the longer you play the more rewards you can get for example you pay have spent all night at a night club and found some girl to talk to and then later got married to her just to find out she is very famous. Even looking into a telescope at night can be rewarding as you can find new planets and stars and name them and get paid for find them. The game can get a little boring for a while doing the same thing over and over again but anyone who is a die hard fan will love the sims 3. verdict The sims 3 is a game where you can do anything and i have not seen anything like it. Even though the game can get borning after awhile its still fun, enjoyable and a great way to pass the time in the real world. I give the sims 3 4/5 stars.

												WHAT CAN I SAY? YOU ARE A PERSON in a PC, PLAYING WITH PEOPLE'S LIVE WHO CAN PLAY WITH PEOPLES LIVES in pc TOO.And you can have ghost babies, and kill your sims in different modes. You can be the villain, the nerd, the vampire, the witch, you can travel through to the future, or to another cities. Choose a job and make career, have pets, do anything. You can build your house the way you want, and put all the peronality on it. Because you can.You can make your own contents or download other player's content, and personalize it.I can spend hours in this game, just in the ''create a sim'' mode. Because imagination flows away. You start thinking about the character, his expressions, his clothes, his personality, and then you go to the part of construction, to build the character's house, and again the time goes by and when you see, you are playing like for 5-7 hours and it's already dawning. And you didn't ''started playing'' yet. Like I said, you can be everything, and do anything. This game is not made for those who seeks action and adventure. Its a simulation game. It's not made of levels for you to beat on. It's endless, and that's one beauty on this game. If it's not your "game type", please don't underestimate the game.

content:
ry 8
												I've owned 1,2 and now 3.  This is easily the best of the 3 versions of this game I have played.  I was a little disappointed at first because start up was a little clunky and confusing.  I'm 45, so take that with a grain of salt.  I also expected a lot more content.  Build mode seems to have more stuff, but I'd have thought there'd be a slew more items in Buy mode, especially since I sprang for Pets, Ambitions and one other pack I can't think of off the top of my head.  The game play is what sold me.  It's so much smoother as far as getting from place to place both within your home and within the town.  It may be partly because of the Ambitions pack, but you can make a lot of meaningful money other than just getting up and going to work ad nauseum.  I also like that life gets easier to manage as a reward for putting in the work.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
er 10, 2016
												The Sims is a series of accelerated modern life simulators that are ideal for people who want a fast break from their real lives. The experience of starting a new game and gradually accumulating money, friends, lovers, kids, and material possessions is fulfilling in an almost RPG-like way. If that concept sounds interesting to you, try this game instead of the rather regressive newer entry in the series, Sims 4. You can often get the main game along with a few expansions in a Steam sale.A couple of warnings: this is a rather old game, and there are sometimes some technical problems. Some of the larger towns such as Isla Paradiso and Lunar Lakes have so many simultaneous NPCs doing stuff in the background that it can cause the game to hang up and freeze for several seconds at a time--sometimes forcing you to use console commands to get everything unstuck. This is unfortunate since those maps are fun to explore. Avoiding exploration in a game because you're worried that it's going to freeze up tends to kill the fun of the experience. This problem even happens on a modern, overclocked 4.3 ghz, 8-core CPU. The game was made before processors like that existed, which is probably part of the problem. The fact that the game has over half a dozen expansions piled on top of it doesn't help, either.Also, there is (or was, perhaps) a bug in which the launcher would not update properly. This got in the way of the game recognizing your EA account, and therefore you couldn't have access to optional items and towns you've purchased in the Sims store. It seems to be working fine now, though.Again, as my hours played probably indicates, this game is a fulfilling time sink if it's something you can get into.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
8, 2014
												A cute and suprisingly fun game. Although it will nag you regularly about it, the game is playable without creating an EA account. If you already have an Origin account with another game, just furnish your Steam product key to link it. Loading times are much longer than I expected, but everything ran fairly smoothly after that. On my first Sim, I noticed a lot of frequent lags as we were waiting for the Grim Reaper to show up. I'm not sure whether it was some background process on my machine or the game itself, but considering that it didn't start until a few days before Death came knocking, I'm tending to believe it's the game. Actions would lag for a second or so a couple or three times per minute. Really annoying. Well worth the price if you can catch it on sale, but definitely not worth the full price tag, especially considering that Sims4 is due out in a couple of months.(EDIT)Forgot a couple of things. When you register the game, you'll get 1000 Sim Points (worth about $10), but it will take some hunting to find them. They'll be on your store account page and will need to be redeemed before you can use them. EA is still EA, so expect to have additional content (microtransactions) dangled in front of you anytime you try to build/buy stuff in-game. Annoying, but totally in keeping with EA, so not surprising.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
er 26, 2013
												I have been playing The Sims games since the original series of games started in the early 2000's. I love this version the best out of all of them. Not just for the game mechanics or graphics, but because It truly defines the world around the sims in way I have not seen before . In many ways allows more modding than The Sims 2 franchise. They also made it so I wanted to buy the expansions (not necessarily a good thing financially), but that really speaks to me of the quality of this game series in particular because this is something I didn't do with the older versions of the this game series. I feel so comfortable with The Sims 3 I actually have no intention of right a way switching to The Sims 4. I might get it if it on sale next year in Holiday Steam Sale.... but I'm okay with sticking with The Sims 3 for a few more years.

content:
8, 2014
												A cute and suprisingly fun game. Although it will nag you regularly about it, the game is playable without creating an EA account. If you already have an Origin account with another game, just furnish your Steam product key to link it. Loading times are much longer than I expected, but everything ran fairly smoothly after that. On my first Sim, I noticed a lot of frequent lags as we were waiting for the Grim Reaper to show up. I'm not sure whether it was some background process on my machine or the game itself, but considering that it didn't start until a few days before Death came knocking, I'm tending to believe it's the game. Actions would lag for a second or so a couple or three times per minute. Really annoying. Well worth the price if you can catch it on sale, but definitely not worth the full price tag, especially considering that Sims4 is due out in a couple of months.(EDIT)Forgot a couple of things. When you register the game, you'll get 1000 Sim Points (worth about $10), but it will take some hunting to find them. They'll be on your store account page and will need to be redeemed before you can use them. EA is still EA, so expect to have additional content (microtransactions) dangled in front of you anytime you try to build/buy stuff in-game. Annoying, but totally in keeping with EA, so not surprising.

content:
27, 2016
My thoughts on The Sims 3The PortThe port is a very interesting one. The options menu is very buggy with the settings sometimes resetting to default as well as sound options taking a bit to actually change or just straight up not changing at all. The video options are varied and nice as well as descriptive but not very informative in terms of certain options, such as edge smoothing, as well as there being no settings for keybinds or mouse sensitivity, besides mouse inverting. Overall the port isn't bad besides some awkward Windows 10 support and performance related issues.The Graphics/PerformanceThe graphics for the game are not the greatest with low res foliage, decent at best textures, awkward lighting and some rather bad modeling. That being said this game was from 2010, was completely open world and obviously needed to compensate for what it was offering. The performance on the other hand is very not good. Actually running the game is absolutly not problem it's very easy to max out the game on even some low end systems but the game is an absolute stuttery mess, even on lower settings. Many people have reported lots of stuttering on high end and low end systems alike. It's a big problem with the game that I can't let slip. It's not very stable at all with its performanceThe Story/Atmosphere/CharactersNon-existant story but the atmosphere of being in a lively environment is very much there but that's all I have to say. I can't really comment on the characters all that much.The ControlsDirect mouse control with keybinds for camera movement and some menu controls. Besides a feeling of mouse acceleration nothing to really say about this.The GameplayThe gameplay is absolutely phenomenal. This is an amazing life simulation game that really feels like you're taking part in, and leading, someone and really being that person. The animation system is absolutely fantastic, besides some bad animation transition, the character interaction is complex and unique and the game as a whole is extremely well done. The AI is a bit stupid and not very good but I can excuse that for how good the rest of this game is. The characted customization is the best I've ever seen, besides maybe Black Dessert Online, with in depth characted facial construction and amazing clothing customization, with the option of creating your own clothing. The only fault is the lack of hair-styles, facial hair, hats and the really crappy body hair and tattoo options but those can be excused.The ConclusionThis game is a fantastic game with many flaws but I would no doubt recommend this to anyone looking for a good simulation game to throw on to waste some time. Not to mention it's one of the good EA games that are on Steam so there's a major plus.The VerdictPort - 7.5/10Graphics - 6/10Performance - 3.5/10Story - *no rating*/10Atmosphere - 9.5/10Characters - *no rating*/10Controls - 8/10Gameplay - 10/10AI - 6.5/10Average Rating - 7/10Actual Rating - 9/10

content:
6, 2016
												Ok my play time doesn't actually show how many hours I've sank into this game just how many I'v accumlated to buy extra content from steam on the cheap. First off your sims 3 codes you buy off Steam now works with EA origins. This is important if you previously own sims packs. Steam makes you buy another copy of the Sims 3 to buy the extra content. Not cool steam its livable. On the good note; during the steam mega sales you can pick up more content for about 4.99 - 9.99. I have all expansions all store content and am missing only one world and a handful of stuff packs. In general I love this game. I've owned it since it came out. Purchased most of my content pre-steam and amazed how cheep you can get stuff for now.  I've scored most of the store content by watching adds on EA and about all my content was purchased for free.  Now that steam has its new controller I am slowly migrating my content onto steam. This is the only sandbox you will ever play that lets you actually make your own video game in whatever style you want. You download the world creator tool and you have hours of interesting things you can do with your game. Program in story lines and challanges for your sims and you have a whole new game. You have the ability to generate maps and new worlds. You get mod content and the sky is the limit.  Lets face facts the sims 3 is just wierd and its not for everyone. How many games do you know that allow you to have ninjas who work as a perfessional jockeys riding unicorns and only eat tofu cheesesteaks?  Now for some of the negative reviews I'm reading. I'm running a top of the line graphics card I play the game on highest levels. I do not have the new nvidia pascals. Only a 970. I have no issues at all. Most of the people who are griping do not realize that there internet cache actually plays a roll on how well the game runs when its in online mode. You donot have to use online mode unless your working on showtime achievements or your planning on buying something in game.  All players need to regularly clean out internet explorer even if you don't use internet explorer to maintain a healthy game.  Because it is how the game originally connect to EA. Most of the lagging etc comes from IE beeing the worst of all the browsers and no ability to change this in your code.  Another issue is too many expansion and stuff packs on at one time. While I run all expansions and all my content most pcs are not capable of doing this. EA suggest limiting how many packs if you want quicker load times.  I don't bother because I use a special mod called Overwatch that peserves the integrity of my game by optimizing the game in other ways that EA didn't think of. Mostly by removing lost sims stray horses and animals and cars that your sims careless forget to drive back home to there houses.  This makes the who game run much smoother and keeps the game from becomming currupt do to user neglect/error.  Mods make this game you can find nearly any type of mod you can imagine. I highly recommend anyone who has ever played minecraft or similar games to give this one a try.
